Question:
How many kinds are produced one after another?
Answer:
The pure dhyÄnas and formless [absorptions] arise in reverse order, forward order, and in succession,
In succession, they give rise to six, seven, eight, nine, and ten.
The pure first dhyÄna gives rise to six kinds in succession, the pure [dhyÄna] of its own stage,
And the pure and uncontaminated second and third dhyÄnas are also like this.
The pure sphere of nothingness gives rise to seven in succession, two of its own stage, one of the higher stage, and four of the lower stage.
The pure second dhyÄna gives rise to eight in succession, two of its own stage, two of the lower stage, and four of the higher stage.
The pure sphere of consciousness gives rise to nine in succession, two of its own stage, three of the higher stage, and four of the lower stage.

The remaining pure [absorptions] give rise to ten in succession, included in the class of subsequent cognition.ğŸ”½The formless [absorptions] succeeding the dhyÄnas do not manifest in the present, not being included in the class of cognition of dharmas.
The class of cognition of dharmas has a lower stage as its basis and lower stage as its object, therefore the formless [absorptions] do not manifest in succession.
Next, two up to ten are born, but not the three of the stage of enjoyment.

From six up to eleven, the pure [attainments] are born in sequence. The pure [attainment] of neither-perception-nor-non-perception gives rise to six kinds: its own stage of enjoyment, pure [attainment], and the four pure [attainments] of the lower stages, as well as the pure [attainment] and the undefiled [attainment]. Because one has already become free from desire [for the stage of neither-perception-nor-non-perception], the [attainment] of enjoyment is not born.
The pure [attainment] of the first trance gives rise to seven: its own stage of three, and the four of the higher stages.
The pure [attainment] and the undefiled [attainment] of the stage of nothingness give rise to eight: its own stage of three, the one of the higher stage, and the four of the lower stages.
The pure [attainment] of the second trance gives rise to nine. The pure [attainment] of the sphere of infinite consciousness gives rise to ten. The rest give rise to eleven.

This refers to the attainment through application and the attainment through freedom from desire, not the attainment through birth. Therefore, the attainment of enjoyment of the lower and higher stages is not mentioned.
When the pure [attainment] ends, it gives rise to all the attainments of enjoyment in sequence.
Question:
Which pure first trance gives rise to the noble path?
Answer:
It refers to the stage of definite progress.
If it were different, it should not be established as four kinds.
Next, two up to ten are born in sequence, but not three.
The first dhyÄna of flavor-pervasion gives rise to two kinds in sequence, its own flavor-pervasion and purity;
not the undefiled, because it is contrary to afflictions;
not the upper stage, because it has not yet abandoned desire.
The three are not born in sequence, but if it is said that three are born, it is not so.
The flavor-pervasion of the second dhyÄna gives rise to four in sequence, two of its own stage, excluding the undefiled;
and two of the lower stage, flavor-pervasion and purity obtained through birth. This is because it fears the craving of the second dhyÄna and protects itself through the pure first dhyÄna.
As the sÅ«tra says, It is better to abide in the first dhyÄna with the thought of disgust and detachment, not to abide in the second dhyÄna with the inferior thought.
The third dhyÄna gives rise to five, two of its own stage, two of the second dhyÄna, and one of the first dhyÄna.
The fourth dhyÄna associated with taste produces six, the sphere of infinite space produces seven, the sphere of infinite consciousness produces eight, and the sphere of nothingness produces nine.

The sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception produces ten, two of its own stage, two of the sphere of nothingness, and six of the lower stage associated with the flavor of meditation, because of the afflictions of rebirth.
Question:
How many kinds does each take as its object?
Answer:
Pure and uncontaminated dhyÄna take all stages as objects,
The objects of the dhyÄna associated with taste are the contaminated dharmas of its own stage.
Pure and uncontaminated dhyÄna take all stages as objects means that pure and uncontaminated dhyÄna take all stages and all kinds as their objects, because their objects are vast.

The class of inferential cognition of the uncontaminated takes eight stages as its object, the class of cognition of the truth of the path takes one stage as its object, and the wholesome roots of expedient means take the four truths as their objects.

As for the objects of the defiled dharmas of one's own stage that are associated with enjoyment, those associated with enjoyment in the first trance state take as objects those associated with enjoyment and purity of one's own stage, not others. This meaning has been extensively explained in the chapter on the defilements. They do not take the undefiled and other stages as objects.
The formless [realms] then do not take as objects the seeds of the defiled [dharmas] of the lower stages.
That is to say, the fundamental wholesome [attainments] have defiled [dharmas] like the trances associated with enjoyment.

The formless [realms] then do not take as objects the seeds of the defiled [dharmas] of the lower stages. That is to say, the fundamental pure and undefiled [attainments] of the formless [realms] do not take the defiled dharmas of the lower stages as objects, because they are free from the characteristics of form.
They take as objects their own stage and higher stages, therefore it is said they are not of the lower [stages].
The class of inferential cognition takes the undefiled [dharmas] of the lower [stages] as objects, therefore it is said they do not have the seeds of the defiled [dharmas].

Because the unobstructed path included in the expedient [means] takes the lower stages as objects, it is said that the fundamental worldly path cuts off the bonds. The unobstructed [path] takes the lower [stages] as objects, and the liberation [path] takes the higher [stages] as objects.
Because those associated with enjoyment take their own stage as objects, it is said they have the wholesome [dharmas].

The defiled one is like the meditation of taste. It is like the meditation associated with taste, which is associated with the meditation on the earth of one's own realm. The formless realm is also like this.
It is said that in the form realm there are immeasurable merits,
which are then said to be the supreme objects of the desire realm.

The immeasurable merits such as the four immeasurables take the desire realm as their object. It has already been said that the supernormal powers are excluded, so the immeasurable merits and so forth are mentioned.

The five supernormal powers take the desire and form realms as their objects. For example, one in the first dhyÄna takes the first dhyÄna and the desire realm as its objects, not the higher stages. The rest are also like this, explained according to their meaning.
The pure meditation is of three kinds:
1. Perfumed by afflictions, 2. Perfumed by the path, 3. Not perfumed.
The perfumed by afflictions refers to the defiled contaminated [meditation] in the stage of regression, because it has the breath of afflictions, it is called perfumed by afflictions.
The perfumed by the path refers to what is perfumed by the path, that is, perfumed cultivation.
The rest are not perfumed.
Question: Which meditations are able to perfume?
Answer:
If one can perfume the dhyÄnas, it is based on the fourth dhyÄna,
because the craving of the three stages is exhausted, the Pure Abodes are only the fruit of fruition.
It is based on the fourth dhyÄna to perfume the first dhyÄna.
Why is it so?
Because it is free from the disturbance of the eight things, and because it is the most excellent of all bases.
There are five kinds of perfuming:
soft, medium, superior, medium-superior, and superior-superior. These give rise to the five kinds of Pure Abodes.
The lower stages also have five kinds of perfuming, but because the craving of the third dhyÄna is exhausted, one does not give rise to the Pure Abodes in the lower stages.

The expedient means of the one who is based on them, whether arising or not arising, arising or not arising, is to enter and not enter samÄdhi. The expedient means is to fully perfect the flow of the fourth dhyÄna without outflows, and then with outflows, and then again without outflows. In that flow, gradually abbreviate, up to two moments without outflows, followed by two moments with outflows appearing in the present. This then perfects the expedient means of perfuming the dhyÄna with both outflows and no outflows.
If one moment is pure, one moment is impure, and one moment is pure again, this is called perfuming meditation. There are fifteen minds:
five impure minds and ten pure minds.
Question:
Why perfume meditation?
Answer:
Either remembering to enter, or fearing afflictions,
Or delighting in rebirth, these are explained according to their meanings.
There are three reasons for perfuming meditation.
Those who remember to enter refer to practitioners who love to enter, in order to abide in bliss in the present life.
Those who fear afflictions refer to those who fear regression.
Those who delight in rebirth refer to those who delight in being born in the Pure Abodes.
Those with liberation through faith have all three reasons for entering.
Those with insight have two, not fearing afflictions because they are not subject to regression.
Those with time-liberation also have two, not delighting in rebirth because they turn their backs on all rebirths.
Those with non-time-liberation have only one, loving to enter.
Because they are not afraid of afflictions and do not regress from the Dharma.
Because they do not delight in birth and turn away from all births.

The nature of the five aggregates perfumed by meditation is contaminated and uncontaminated, with the four truths as objects. Uncontaminated and contaminated are like scattering uncontaminated flowers on a stupa. This is the meaning of perfuming. It is explained in detail like this.
The uncontaminated mind perfumes the contaminated mind, like scattering flowers on a stupa.
Question:
The three kinds of correct meditative absorption have already been explained. How are they attained?
Answer:
One attains pure meditation through detachment and rebirth,
while defiled [meditation] regresses and is born. The uncontaminated [meditation] is only attained through detachment.
One attains pure first meditation at two times:
Through detachment from desire for the desire realm and through falling from higher stages and being born in the Brahma heaven.
Question:

One also attains it through regression, that is, through regression from detachment from desire for the first meditation, one attains the wholesome roots of the stage of regression of the first meditation.
Why is it not explained?
Answer:
Here it is said that all pure [attainments] are attained without having been attained before.

When regressing, although one attains the wholesome roots of the category of regression without having attained them before, one loses the other three [categories] and attains the one [category of regression]. Now, one loses the three [categories] and attains the one [category of regression]. It is not that they did not exist before, so it is not that all [attainments] are attained without having been attained before. Therefore, it is not explained.
Can one attain the pure first dhyÄna through detachment, and also attain, lose, regress, and be reborn in the same way through detachment?
Answer:

There is the first dhyÄna of the category of regression, which is attained when detaching from the desire realm, and lost when detaching from the Brahma heaven. When detaching from the Brahma heaven, one loses the superior category, etc., and thus loses the category of regression.
When regressing from detachment from the Brahma heaven, one attains it. When regressing from detachment from the desire realm, one loses it.
When falling from the higher realms and being reborn in the Brahma heaven, one attains it. When falling from the Brahma heaven and being reborn in the desire realm, one loses it.
Up to the sphere of nothingness, it is the same.
Detachment from the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is attained, not attained through birth, because there are no higher realms.

The defiled ones are obtained by regression and birth. The defiled first dhyÄna is obtained when regressing from the first dhyÄna. When one regresses from the desire realm and the entanglements of the Brahma heavens,

the obtained by birth is when one falls from the upper realms and is born in the desire realm and the Brahma heavens. In this way, up to the sphere of nothingness and the neither perception nor non-perception. Only regression is obtained.
The pure ones are only obtained by detachment. The pure first dhyÄna is obtained by detachment. When the noble ones detach from the desire realm, this refers to the person who proceeds in stages.
If one relies on the first dhyÄna to transcend birth and enter the formless realm, it is also obtained. In this way, up to all stages.
Question:
What afflictions are eliminated by these various merits?
Answer:
The pure ones eliminate afflictions and the intermediate attainment,
all the intermediate concentrations are associated with the faculty of equanimity.

The pure ones eliminate afflictions. The fundamental pure first dhyÄna is the antidote to the afflictions of eight stages, up to the sphere of nothingness which is the antidote to the afflictions of two stages.
As for the intermediate state of proper reception, the intermediate state of proper reception is called the path of skillful means, referring to the severing of afflictions of the lower stages.
Until one has not yet severed the desires of the lower stages, one cannot attain the fundamental proper reception.
The rest are not antidotes.
All intermediate states associated with the path of skillful means are associated with the faculty of equanimity, because one has not yet attained and thus does not give rise to joy.
Question:
As it is said, the upper stages have no body consciousness.
If one in the upper stages desires to see with the eyes, hear with the ears, or touch with the body, how does one see, hear, or touch?
Answer:
The consciousness of the Brahma world appears before one.
Question:
Why does the upper stage not have this consciousness?
Answer:
It has been said before that in the upper stages, initial and sustained thought are not present, and thus there are no three types of body consciousness.

If one in the upper stages desires to see, hear, or touch, the consciousness of the first trance appears before one and one then sees, hears, or touches, but not through the desire realm or as a result of cultivation.
Question:
At what time is it accomplished?
Answer:
According to which consciousness is present, one accomplishes the higher stages.
If one abandons them, one does not accomplish them, because the power of the mind is weak.

Up to when this consciousness is present, whether eye consciousness, ear consciousness, or body consciousness, at that time one accomplishes them, because the weak mind is not obscured and indeterminate.
Therefore, one accomplishes them in a moment, and after arising from them, one does not continue to possess them.
Question:
One already knows the time of accomplishing wholesome and defiled meditative attainments and the accomplishment of various consciousnesses.
How does one obtain the mind of transformation?
How many minds are obtained at once?
Answer:
One obtains these minds of transformation through rebirth and detachment,
two, three, and four, and also five, obtained at once.
There are two causes and conditions for obtaining the mind of transformation:
rebirth and detachment.

One who is reborn may suddenly obtain two, three, four, or five. When one who has died in the higher stages is reborn in the Brahma Heaven, at that time one obtains the two minds of the fruit of the first trance:
one of the desire realm and one of the first trance.
If born in the second dhyÄna, one obtains three minds:
one of the desire realm, one of the first dhyÄna, and one of one's own stage.
If born in the third dhyÄna, one obtains four minds:
three of lower stages and one of one's own stage.
If born in the fourth dhyÄna, one obtains five minds:
four of lower stages and one of one's own stage.
This is said to be obtained through rebirth.
One who is free from desire obtains two minds, as explained before.

One free from desire of the first dhyÄna obtains three minds, one free from desire of the second dhyÄna obtains four minds, and one free from desire of the third dhyÄna obtains five minds. Therefore it is said that one may obtain a mind of transformation in a single moment without eliminating it.
When one is free from desire of the desire realm, the final unobstructed path makes four statements.

Obtained but not eliminated means when one is free from desire of the desire realm, the mind of transformation of the fruit of the first dhyÄna is obtained. This mind is bound by the fetters of the first dhyÄna and therefore not eliminated.

Those that are eliminated but not obtained refer to the three levels of transformation minds that are the fruits of the second, third, and fourth dhyÄnas in the desire realm. Because these are dharmas of the desire realm, they are bound by the afflictions of the desire realm. When the bonds of desire for the desire realm are eliminated, one does not obtain [the transformation minds] of the first dhyÄna because one has not yet eliminated desire for the first dhyÄna.
Those that are both obtained and eliminated refer to the transformation minds that are the fruits of the desire realm and the first dhyÄna.
Those that are neither obtained nor eliminated refer to the remaining transformation minds.
Up to the elimination of desire for the third dhyÄna, the meaning is explained according to the principle.
Among these fourteen transformation minds, there are four in the desire realm and ten in the form realm.

Those transformation minds of the desire realm create transformations of the desire realm, and those transformation minds of the form realm create transformations of the form realm, because they are of the same level as oneself.
Those transformations are of eight kinds:
Being born in the desire realm, one transforms the desire realm, transforming one's own body and the bodies of others. Being born in the form realm, one transforms the form realm in the same way.
The transformations of the desire realm have four sense bases, and the transformations of the form realm have two sense bases.
Why is this?
Because the sense faculties are not transformed.
Therefore, the transformation has no mind, one mind and one transformation, or many, but only one stage.
Abiding in the supernormal powers can cause abiding.

Although in nirvana, the transformation still turns, like when the Venerable DhyÄna entered nirvana, his transformation fire burned his body, and the Venerable MahÄkÄÅ›yapa's whole body remained for a long time.
The World-Honored One's transformation teaching is not a part of the Buddha's work, so he entered parinirvÄá¹‡a without leaving a transformation.
Question:
Is the transformation of cultivated wisdom also the wisdom of birth?
Answer:
One can also be born with the wisdom of transformation and then regress. Therefore, it is the cultivated wisdom obtained through first detaching from desire.
The mind of transformation of the demon heavens is the wisdom of birth.
Like when a demon transforms into the body of a Buddha, a female demon transforms her body and goes to where the Buddha is, or when a transformed person eats food.
If the host of the transformation originally wanted to nourish their own body, then the food they eat is digested in the body of the host of the transformation.
If they originally did not want to nourish their body, then the food only accumulates in the place of the transformed person.
Question:
How many kinds of transformation minds are accomplished?
Answer:
Or two, three, four, five, seven, and nine,
Increasing by three or also five, thus accomplishing transformation minds.

If born in the desire realm, with desire for desire extinguished, but desire for Brahma Heaven not yet extinguished, and born in Brahma Heaven, with desire for it not yet extinguished, then two are accomplished.
If born in the second dhyana, with desire for it not yet extinguished, then three are accomplished.
If born in the third dhyana, with desire for it not yet extinguished, then four are accomplished.
If born in the fourth dhyana, then five are accomplished.
If born in the desire realm or Brahma Heaven, with desire for Brahma Heaven extinguished, but desire for the second dhyana not yet extinguished, then five are also accomplished.
If born in the second dhyana, with desire for the second dhyana extinguished, but desire for the third dhyana not yet extinguished, then seven are accomplished.

Thus, it should be said that there are nine, and by adding three and five, when the craving for the fourth meditation is exhausted, one is born in the third meditation, and when born in the second meditation, one adds three more, and when born in the first meditation, one adds five more.
Question:
If the transformation of the desire realm is the fruit of the first meditation, and the transformation of the first meditation stage is the fruit of the first meditation, what is the difference?
Answer:
Because the realm of the form realm is superior, it is superior.

Moreover, the fruit of the second meditation in the desire realm, and the fruit of the first meditation in the form realm, because the desire realm can go to the second meditation and is superior, it is said to be superior in going, and the form realm is superior in realm.

All transformations are explained like this. The mind of transformation obtained through detachment and the mind of transformation obtained through skillful means each have fourteen kinds. When one is born in a lower stage, one obtains the fourteen kinds obtained through previous detachment.
